clinical_study.brief_title: Remifentanil Requirement for Acceptable Intubating Condition
clinical_study.official_title: Remifentanil Requirement for Acceptable Intubating Condition With Two Dose Ketamine Without Neuromuscular Blocking Agent in Children

brief_summary.textblock: Ketamine and opioid are known to improve the intubating condition, respectively. Combination of ketamine and opioid potentiate analgesic effect and give hemodynamic stability in complementary manner. Therefore, the combination use of ketamine and remifentanil could be useful for acceptable intubating condition in the general anesthesia without the use of neuromuscular blocking agent. Generally, induction dose of ketamine ranges between 1 and 2 mg. There was no report about the optimal dose of remifentanil with 1 or 2 mg ketamine induction dose for intubation without neuromuscular blocking agent. The investigators focus on remifentanil dose using Dixon's up and down method.

primary_outcome.time_frame: during and after intubation, about 2 minute
primary_outcome.description: For assessment of intubation condition, 5 variables will be individually evaluated though 3 point scale (excellent, good, poor). If all variables are graded as excellent, intubation condition will be excellent. If at least 1 variable is poor, it will be reported as poor. Otherwise, it will be reported as good. Good and excellent will be considered to be acceptable intubating condition. Poor will be reported as unacceptable intubating condition. Laryngoscope easiness Vocal cord position Vocal cord movement Movement of limb Coughing

arm_group.description: Anesthesia induction with ketamine 1 mg followed by remifentanil.
Anesthesia induction with ketamine 2 mg followed by remifentanil.

intervention.description: Anesthesia induction is performed with 1 mg ketamine.
Anesthesia induction is performed with 2 mg ketamine.
After anesthesia induction with ketamine, predetermined remifentanil using Dixon's up and dowm method is administered.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- ASA I-II
- Undergoing general anesthesia with endotracheal tube
Exclusion Criteria:
- Anticipated difficult airway
- Patient with upper respiratory infection within 14 days
- Asthma
